Issues.Title: Add Warning in WindowsDesktop SDK for UseWinForms
Issues.Body:
See https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/1027#issuecomment-505092719 

The comment from @drewnoakes suggests that there is occasional confusion that leads to the use of `UseWinForms` in `Microsoft.NET.Sdk.WindowsDesktop` based projects instead of using the correct property `UseWindowsForms`. 

The current behavior will be warning `NETSDK1106` ("Windows Desktop SDK requires UseWpf or UseWindowsForms"). This should help the vast majority of WinForms projects that guess the property name wrong. 

The small number of projects that try to set `UseWpf` and `UseWinForms` (instead of the correct property `UseWindowsForms`) will not receive any warnings today. 

We should evaluate whether a new warning is needed to help those who set `UseWinForms` and add it to the WindowsDesktop SDK. 

/cc @merriemcgaw, @OliaG
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add Warning in WindowsDesktop SDK for UseWinForms " (#1226)

Issues.Title: Enable the Visual Basic Windows Forms Application Framework
Issues.Body: Visual Basic in classic .NET had the ability to configure a series of application settings just via the App Designer. The following screenshot shows the Application Framework part of the AppDesigner for Visual Basic projects: We should consider reenable this for VB Core projects. Here are my suggestions, what functionality we should include in the first step/version for the VB Application designer: * **Enable Visual Basic application framework:** Should enable or disable the whole application framework support for a VB WinForms project. (Was: _Enable application framework_) * **Enable visual styles:** Should enable rendering of common controls in V6 style (rather than V5 style). This is the equivilant to executing the method Application.EnableVisualStyles, before the main form has been rendered initially on the screen. (Was: _Enable XP visual styles)_ * **HighDpi mode:** Allows the user to pick the desired HighDpi mode from a combo box. Default should be _SystemAware_. * **Make single instance application:** In Windows, there is no way that an app cannot be started multiple times. What can be done, though, is to check if the same name already runs, and then close that app if that's the case. This is exactly what _Make single instance application does_. (Naming would not change). [Edited for clarity]. * **Shutdown mode:** Lets the user pick under what condition a VB WinForms should be shut down. Options are _When startup form closes_, _when last form closes_. (Naming would not change). * **Save my settings on Shutdown:** Automates `Properties.Settings.Default.Save()` on shutting down a Visual Basic Forms App. (Naming would not change). * **Edit Application Events Code**: Creates a file _ApplicationEvents.vb_, if that does not exist yet, opens the code editor, and lets the user add/edit code for the predefined events `NetworkAvailabilityChanged`, `ShutDown`, `StartUp`, `StartUpNextInstance`, `UnhandledException`. (Was: _View Application Events_). The first step to enable this - apart from the AppDesigner work for the Visual Basic Project Properties Dialog - would be to port `WinFormsApplicationBase` (inherited from `ConsoleApplicationBase`, already ported to Core) over to Core and adjust it accordingly to these specs. **Note/Disclaimer:** This description does not claim an exact technical functionality, but should suggest the scope of the 1st version of the VB Application Framework.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enable the Visual Basic Windows Forms Application Framework" (#1216)
